repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem:  No way to have extmarks automatically removed when the line it
          is attached to is deleted.
Solution: Add new 'invalidate' property that will remove marks when the
          line it is attached to is deleted when set to "line".

comment_data.body:
I don't think lumping in `ephemeral` extmarks with a concept of extmark invalidation (as an active response to events) really makes sense. 

IMO I would call this option `"Invalidate"` or something like that, where `"line"` is the current only value (but leaves the door open to invalidate the extmark on other conditions in the future, like deleting the range of chars instead of the line). And then leave `ephemeral` be what it is.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2684,6 +2684,17 @@ nvim_buf_set_extmark({buffer}, {ns_id}, {line}, {col}, {*opts})
                     • "blend": blend with background text color. Not supported
                       for "inline" virt_text.
 
+                  • lifetime : control the lifetime of the mark.

comment_data.body: Fine by me. I just went with @lewis6991's suggestion to be able to move forward with the sign refactor.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2684,6 +2684,17 @@ nvim_buf_set_extmark({buffer}, {ns_id}, {line}, {col}, {*opts})
                     • "blend": blend with background text color. Not supported
                       for "inline" virt_text.
 
+                  • lifetime : control the lifetime of the mark.

comment_data.body:
I'm happy if we keep this separate from `ephemeral` and call it `invalidate`, however I would like us to align on what `ephemeral` really means and how it conceptually differs to `invalidate`.

Conceptually I understood ephemeral extmarks to be invalidated/removed at the end of the redraw cycle, which is why I suggested combining these together. I thought this would work out nicely since these options are mutually exclusive and thus reduces entropy and ambiguity.

I know internally they are implemented by skipping the marktree and are applied to the redraw state directly, but isn't that just an implementation detail?

Is there a more accurate description we can update `ephemeral` to so the difference between that and `invalidate` is more conceptually distinct?  I guess one significant difference is that `ephemeral` marks can't be inspected with `nvim_buf_get_extmarks`, though this could be treated as a caveat rather than a defining property.

For reference here's the current description:

```
                  • ephemeral : for use with |nvim_set_decoration_provider()|
                    callbacks. The mark will only be used for the current
                    redraw cycle, and not be permantently stored in the
                    buffer.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2684,6 +2684,17 @@ nvim_buf_set_extmark({buffer}, {ns_id}, {line}, {col}, {*opts})
                     • "blend": blend with background text color. Not supported
                       for "inline" virt_text.
 
+                  • lifetime : control the lifetime of the mark.

comment_data.body:
Ok, I agree that decoration providers and ephemeral extmarks are underdocumented, both in concept and detail.

For reference, after having them and using them for some while, I think the refactor of the interface that _would_ make sense is more like this: (not saying it has to be done, but it would be more conceptually transparent). Deprecate `ephemeral=true` as suggested. But then do this: add a new lua-only function `vim.decoration_provider_emit_decoration()` . This is no longer an "extmark" which lives for any period of time, but just an event (or "yielded value" of a generator, etc)  which is fired in response in a lua event handler. "decoration" is no longer a synonym to "decorated extmark", but a valid thing on its own. (then we can speak of "ephemeral decorations" in contrast to "extmarks with decorations").

I'd be happy to expand more on this (and at least improve the documentation if not more) after some refactors to the internals I am currently working on.

>  I guess one significant difference is that ephemeral marks can't be inspected with nvim_buf_get_extmarks, though this could be treated as a caveat rather than a defining property.

It is a caveat that they cannot be logged/introspected in in-process tests _at all_, but it is a defining property that they cannot be inspected the same way. an added inspection interface will be more like inspecting an event log (not inspecting any "state").
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2684,6 +2684,17 @@ nvim_buf_set_extmark({buffer}, {ns_id}, {line}, {col}, {*opts})
                     • "blend": blend with background text color. Not supported
                       for "inline" virt_text.
 
+                  • lifetime : control the lifetime of the mark.

comment_data.body:
> Deprecate `ephemeral=true` as suggested. But then do this: add a new lua-only function `vim.decoration_provider_emit_decoration()`

Sounds good to me. But there is no need to deprecate `ephemeral=true` here then right? Can just be deprecated whenever this replacement `ephemeral decoration` interface is added.

Do we then go ahead with a boolean `invalidate` property? Or `invalidate == 'line'` or `invalidate == { 'line',  <???> }`?

(Happy to do it (remove the documentation for the flag) here if it is better done sooner rather than later. It's just no longer really related to this PR if we don't add a replacing property/interface here.)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2684,6 +2684,17 @@ nvim_buf_set_extmark({buffer}, {ns_id}, {line}, {col}, {*opts})
                     • "blend": blend with background text color. Not supported
                       for "inline" virt_text.
 
+                  • lifetime : control the lifetime of the mark.

comment_regular_data.body: This is not a breaking change, right?
Guess not, `ephemeral` is soft deprecated. (Are there any additional guidelines I didn't follow for soft deprecating API argument properties?)

Ideally `invalidate` should be range based and not line based. E.g. when a word is deleted with `dw`, the extmarks within the deleted word are also deleted. However I appreciate this may be more complicated to implement so either:

1. keep the logic here internal to #25724 and expose this later when we can do it more generally for ranges.
2. add `line` as an unstable option by prefixing with `_` to `_line` so we can change `_line` -> `range` at a later date without incurring the cost of a deprecation cycle. 
3. simply go with this PR and accept both `line` and `range` going forward.

My preference here in order would be 2, 1, 3.

What do you think?

Hmm not sure, I guess `"line"` will indeed become redundant when `"range"` is implemented. So in that sense going with 2. or 1. might be better. Do we have precedent for adding unstable args keys? I'm fine with either. But yeah I suspect supporting mark removal when the range is deleted will be more difficult so having the unstable flag in the meantime might be nice.

Atm the only unstable API elements are:
- functions prefixed with `nvim__`.
- `_hl_def` and `_on_spell_nav` in `nvim_set_decorartion_provider`, however they are undocumented.

So maybe we add this to the API without documenting?

I believe `line` would be inclusive to `range`, so perhaps `invalidate` can just be a boolean for now, until other invalidation reasons are added, if ever. Nothing user-facing would have to change when we can support range removal, except the documentation? It can be made an `Object` if other invalidation reasons are ever added.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: feat(extmark): add 'invalidate' property to extmarks
